issue.title: Using QUIC as a general purpose protocol
issue.body:
Hello,

If I want to use ngtcp2 as the transport protocol and run another application (such as VNC) over it, which example can help? simpleclient for example?

comment.body:
Hi Phillip,

Thanks for your hints. 

Yes I want to start from simpleclient.c to implement a relay program that can read from a port and write to QUIC streams or read from streams and write to a port.
This way other applications can connect to this program by port forwarding at both client and server sides.

issue.title: NGTCP2_PROTO_VER_MAX is set to NGTCP2_PROTO_VER_V1
issue.body:
Shouldn't it be set to NGTCP2_PROTO_VER_V2?

Also, what is the intended use case for this, and will it work properly with non-consecutive version numbers (V1 = 1, V2 = 0x6b3343cf; maybe for V3 the value will go down not up?).

If it's not suitable for any use case, maybe we should just get rid of it?  I don't see NGTCP2_PROTO_VER_MIN or NGTCP2_PROTO_VER_MAX being used anywhere in the library itself.

comment.body: Yeah, quic v2 codepoint is unexpected, and our macros can not deal with it.  I agree that they should be deprecated for now.

issue.title: Webtransport over ngtcp2
issue.body: Do you have any plan to implement WebTransport?

comment.body: Any updates? The only other option is google's quiche but it seem like a pain to build without using bazel.

issue.title: How to add personalized transport parameters?
issue.body:
How can I simply add personalized transport parameters in QUIC packet?
If I only need to add some variables in "client.cc" and "server.cc", or change some files like "ngtcp2_crypto.cc" in the lib folder?
Thanks.

issue.title: Using QUIC as a general purpose protocol
issue.body:
Hello,

If I want to use ngtcp2 as the transport protocol and run another application (such as VNC) over it, which example can help? simpleclient for example?

comment.body:
I found the [quic-echo](https://gitlab.com/dueno/quic-echo) demo program to be a helpful non-http example, though it has not been maintained so it is somewhat out-of-date now.

ngtcp2 itself also has simpleclient.c for a non-http example, but it's just the client not server, and it also may not be up-to-date.

issue.title: NGTCP2_PROTO_VER_MAX is set to NGTCP2_PROTO_VER_V1
issue.body:
Shouldn't it be set to NGTCP2_PROTO_VER_V2?

Also, what is the intended use case for this, and will it still work properly when the version numbers are not consecutive (V1 = 1, V2 = 0x6b3343cf).

If not, maybe should just get rid of it?  I don't see NGTCP2_PROTO_VER_MIN or NGTCP2_PROTO_VER_MAX being used anywhere in the library itself.

issue.title: Crash after upgrade to v1.0.0
issue.body:
Hi. I have been using the v0.16.0 version previously, which has always been very stable. After upgrading to the v1.0.0 version, users reported crashes, and the specific crash report is as follows:

```
Exception Type:  SIGSEGV
Exception Codes: SEGV_MAPERR at 0xb

0   ngtcp2_pkt_encode_datagram_frame (ngtcp2_pkt.c:2035)
1   ngtcp2_ppe_encode_frame (ngtcp2_ppe.c:95)
2   conn_ppe_write_frame_hd_log (ngtcp2_conn.c:1805)
3   conn_write_pkt (ngtcp2_conn.c:4031)
4   ngtcp2_conn_write_vmsg (ngtcp2_conn.c:12195)
5   ngtcp2_conn_writev_datagram_versioned (ngtcp2_conn.c:11895)
```

Please let me know if you need more information.

comment.body: Thank you for your explanation, I will check the code again and continue to observe this issue, and share with you when there is more information.

issue.title: Crash after upgrade to v1.0.0
issue.body:
Hi. I have been using the v0.16.0 version previously, which has always been very stable. After upgrading to the v1.0.0 version, users reported crashes, and the specific crash report is as follows:

```
Exception Type:  SIGSEGV
Exception Codes: SEGV_MAPERR at 0xb

0   ngtcp2_pkt_encode_datagram_frame (ngtcp2_pkt.c:2035)
1   ngtcp2_ppe_encode_frame (ngtcp2_ppe.c:95)
2   conn_ppe_write_frame_hd_log (ngtcp2_conn.c:1805)
3   conn_write_pkt (ngtcp2_conn.c:4031)
4   ngtcp2_conn_write_vmsg (ngtcp2_conn.c:12195)
5   ngtcp2_conn_writev_datagram_versioned (ngtcp2_conn.c:11895)
```

Please let me know if you need more information.

comment.body:
Thank you.  They seem to be coincidentally the same value.
In general, when the memory related problem occurs, the behavior of a program is undefined.   That means any data can be overwritten with the seemingly random data.  Not still fully understand why the value is there though.

issue.title: Crash after upgrade to v1.0.0
issue.body:
Hi. I have been using the v0.16.0 version previously, which has always been very stable. After upgrading to the v1.0.0 version, users reported crashes, and the specific crash report is as follows:

```
Exception Type:  SIGSEGV
Exception Codes: SEGV_MAPERR at 0xb

0   ngtcp2_pkt_encode_datagram_frame (ngtcp2_pkt.c:2035)
1   ngtcp2_ppe_encode_frame (ngtcp2_ppe.c:95)
2   conn_ppe_write_frame_hd_log (ngtcp2_conn.c:1805)
3   conn_write_pkt (ngtcp2_conn.c:4031)
4   ngtcp2_conn_write_vmsg (ngtcp2_conn.c:12195)
5   ngtcp2_conn_writev_datagram_versioned (ngtcp2_conn.c:11895)
```

Please let me know if you need more information.

comment.body:
No. 0xb should be an address. Here are some similar reports from other crashes.

```
Exception Type:  SIGSEGV
Exception Codes: SEGV_MAPERR at 0x8
```

```
Exception Type:  SIGSEGV
Exception Codes: SEGV_MAPERR at 0x1e
```

```
Exception Type:  SIGSEGV
Exception Codes: SEGV_MAPERR at 0x21a1fdca2939
```

```
Exception Type:  SIGSEGV
Exception Codes: SEGV_MAPERR at 0x656e69676e655420
```

issue.title: Crash after upgrade to v1.0.0
issue.body:
Hi. I have been using the v0.16.0 version previously, which has always been very stable. After upgrading to the v1.0.0 version, users reported crashes, and the specific crash report is as follows:

```
Exception Type:  SIGSEGV
Exception Codes: SEGV_MAPERR at 0xb

0   ngtcp2_pkt_encode_datagram_frame (ngtcp2_pkt.c:2035)
1   ngtcp2_ppe_encode_frame (ngtcp2_ppe.c:95)
2   conn_ppe_write_frame_hd_log (ngtcp2_conn.c:1805)
3   conn_write_pkt (ngtcp2_conn.c:4031)
4   ngtcp2_conn_write_vmsg (ngtcp2_conn.c:12195)
5   ngtcp2_conn_writev_datagram_versioned (ngtcp2_conn.c:11895)
```

Please let me know if you need more information.

comment.body:
After 0.16.0, I made some fixes in the related code so that NGTCP2_ERR_STREAM_DATA_BLOCKED is returned where it should.  The fix makes the code consistent to the function specification, but it could introduce the side effect in the existing code.

I think 0xb is the signal code for SIGSEGV, not an address.

comment.body: Yes, I understand, but in this case, should the SEGV_MAPERR error address be a random high address rather than 0xb?

issue.title: Crash after upgrade to v1.0.0
issue.body:
Hi. I have been using the v0.16.0 version previously, which has always been very stable. After upgrading to the v1.0.0 version, users reported crashes, and the specific crash report is as follows:

```
Exception Type:  SIGSEGV
Exception Codes: SEGV_MAPERR at 0xb

0   ngtcp2_pkt_encode_datagram_frame (ngtcp2_pkt.c:2035)
1   ngtcp2_ppe_encode_frame (ngtcp2_ppe.c:95)
2   conn_ppe_write_frame_hd_log (ngtcp2_conn.c:1805)
3   conn_write_pkt (ngtcp2_conn.c:4031)
4   ngtcp2_conn_write_vmsg (ngtcp2_conn.c:12195)
5   ngtcp2_conn_writev_datagram_versioned (ngtcp2_conn.c:11895)
```

Please let me know if you need more information.

comment.body: buf is initialized with the given external buffer that application gives to the ngtcp2 functions.  If buf is stack allocated, and ngtcp2_conn_writev_stream or ngtcp2_conn_writev_datagram do not fully produce a packet or there is no packet to be made, buf keeps dangling pointer.

issue.title: Crash after upgrade to v1.0.0
issue.body:
Hi. I have been using the v0.16.0 version previously, which has always been very stable. After upgrading to the v1.0.0 version, users reported crashes, and the specific crash report is as follows:

```
Exception Type:  SIGSEGV
Exception Codes: SEGV_MAPERR at 0xb

0   ngtcp2_pkt_encode_datagram_frame (ngtcp2_pkt.c:2035)
1   ngtcp2_ppe_encode_frame (ngtcp2_ppe.c:95)
2   conn_ppe_write_frame_hd_log (ngtcp2_conn.c:1805)
3   conn_write_pkt (ngtcp2_conn.c:4031)
4   ngtcp2_conn_write_vmsg (ngtcp2_conn.c:12195)
5   ngtcp2_conn_writev_datagram_versioned (ngtcp2_conn.c:11895)
```

Please let me know if you need more information.

comment.body:
Yes. I'm using NGTCP2_WRITE_STREAM_FLAG_MORE.

However, I have never observed this issue in version v0.16.0, but due to some modifications in the related code, it cannot be fully confirmed whether it is caused by upgrading to v1.0.0. I have already downgraded back to v0.16.0 to see if the crash will still occur.

Additionally, I guess you think that the buffer has been released when accessing the written buffer, causing access to invalid memory. But combined with the error report `SEGV_MAPERR at 0xb`, it suggests that there should be a problem with the buf->last parameter when ngtcp2_ppe_encode_frame (ngtcp2_ppe.c:95) calls ngtcp2_pkt_encode_datagram_frame. This should not be a problem caused by external data.

issue.title: Crash after upgrade to v1.0.0
issue.body:
Hi. I have been using the v0.16.0 version previously, which has always been very stable. After upgrading to the v1.0.0 version, users reported crashes, and the specific crash report is as follows:

```
Exception Type:  SIGSEGV
Exception Codes: SEGV_MAPERR at 0xb

0   ngtcp2_pkt_encode_datagram_frame (ngtcp2_pkt.c:2035)
1   ngtcp2_ppe_encode_frame (ngtcp2_ppe.c:95)
2   conn_ppe_write_frame_hd_log (ngtcp2_conn.c:1805)
3   conn_write_pkt (ngtcp2_conn.c:4031)
4   ngtcp2_conn_write_vmsg (ngtcp2_conn.c:12195)
5   ngtcp2_conn_writev_datagram_versioned (ngtcp2_conn.c:11895)
```

Please let me know if you need more information.

comment.body: Thank you.  Are you using NGTCP2_WRITE_STREAM_FLAG_MORE flag with ngtcp2_conn_writev_stream?  The flag name is different, but the underlying machinery is shared.

issue.title: Crash after upgrade to v1.0.0
issue.body:
Hi. I have been using the v0.16.0 version previously, which has always been very stable. After upgrading to the v1.0.0 version, users reported crashes, and the specific crash report is as follows:

```
Exception Type:  SIGSEGV
Exception Codes: SEGV_MAPERR at 0xb

0   ngtcp2_pkt_encode_datagram_frame (ngtcp2_pkt.c:2035)
1   ngtcp2_ppe_encode_frame (ngtcp2_ppe.c:95)
2   conn_ppe_write_frame_hd_log (ngtcp2_conn.c:1805)
3   conn_write_pkt (ngtcp2_conn.c:4031)
4   ngtcp2_conn_write_vmsg (ngtcp2_conn.c:12195)
5   ngtcp2_conn_writev_datagram_versioned (ngtcp2_conn.c:11895)
```

Please let me know if you need more information.

comment.body: If you use NGTCP2_WRITE_DATAGRAM_FLAG_MORE, make sure that the return value from ngtcp2_conn_writev_datagram is properly handled.  The buffer given to the function should not change until it produces a packet or returns 0.

issue.title: cmake: re-add two missing includes
issue.body:
Previously these were were included transitively via `cmake/ExtractValidFlags.cmake`. #964 deleted that file. The replacements it added pulled these includes after the local code uses them when `ENABLE_ASAN` enabled.

Re-add these includes into the `CMakeLists.txt` that uses them.

Reported-by: fpliu
Fixes #979

comment.body: Thank you for PR.  Merged now.

commits.message: Bump library versions due to the patch release

release.name: ngtcp2 v1.0.1
release.body:
## What's Changed
* crypto: Fix bug that retry token AAD does not include QUIC version by @tatsuhiro-t in https://github.com/ngtcp2/ngtcp2/pull/985

**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/ngtcp2/ngtcp2/compare/v1.0.0...v1.0.1
release.short_description_html:
What's Changed

  • crypto: Fix bug that retry token AAD does not include QUIC version by @tatsuhiro-t in #985

Full Changelog: v1.0.0...v1.0.1
